div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: SIR E. GREY ON EGYPT.
div.p: Sir E. Grey's references to Egypt in his speech on the Foreign Office vote, as summarised by the telegrams which we have published, will be accepted by all, save by the small ultra-nationalist party, as still one more indication of our desire to direct the Government of the country in the interests of the people and to meet as far as possible their wishes. Regarding the question of revising the sentences inflicted upon those found guilty of active participation in the Denishwai outrage, the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs referred to the necessity of making a very severe example of the convicted, and pointed out the langer of an act of clemency being misconstrued into one of weakness. He gave every hope, however, that there would be a revision of sentences "when the state of feeling neccesitating a severe example had passed." But, unfortunately for all, there exists in Egypt a psuedo-nationalist press, which immoderately denounces England's every action regarding this country, which refuses to believe that an English official can act for the good of the country or administrate with wisdom, which loudly decries our every effort on behalf of the people, and which-in fine-gives the impression that a fanatical and hysterical spirit is existent. The cry of this press is "give us selfgovernment," but they refuse to recognise that by their irrationality they harm the very cause for which they so vociferously shout. We trust the day will come when an the day the act of clemency, such as the revision of the sentences on the Denishwai prisoners, will not be accepted as an act of weakness, when the supporters of Mustapha Kamel and his colleagues will plead their cause in such a spirit as to show us that it is possible of favourable consideration, and persuade us that they are genuine and disinterested wellwishers of their country, capable of reasonable action. As Sir E. Grey remarked, the withdrawal of British influence would re-open the door to corruption, oppression, and injustice. The Egypt of to-day has sprung into existence in an unparalleled short space of time, and the education of the people is by no means completed. The necessity for a guiding and protecting hand is acknowledged by all whose opinion is of weight, and we are glad to recognise that our policy receives support from the highest quarters and all advanced Egyptians, while the poorer classes are quietly appreciative of the benefits we have conferred upon them. The only possible fruit of the violent policy pursued by certain of our confrères is distrust, for such agitation only strengthens the conviction that a quarter of a century's continuous rule under the immediate influence of the highest western civilisation has been insufficient to import to the nation the wisdom and moderation necessary for self: government.
JAPAN'S EGYPT.

On the situation in Korea the "Nation" remarks:-"Japan has brought about the ab- dication of the Emperor as England and France brought about the fall of the Khedive Ismail, and Korean independence enters upon a new phase. It is possible to exaggerate the import- ance of the event. Even to the Emperor the difference between reigning and abdicating must be little more than verbal. The only function of anindependent sovereign which had remained to him since the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese war was the right of signing under protest He has exercised it to the last

Were Korea a Japanese province the pros perity of the whole population would be a national interest, while the natives would be Japanese subjects, who would enjoy civil, and might ultimately aspire to political equality with the conquerors. As a mere sphere of influence it is simply a field to be developed by Japanese syndicates and colonised by Japanese veterans. One hears already of the wholesale expropriation of land and the imposition of the corvée, It is this material exploitation rather than the outrage of Korean nationality which is the really sinister aspect of this in- direct conquest."

div.head: Cairo Gang of Burglar*.
div.p: The1 Cairo City police are apparently very much occupied with an expert band of burglars who are working the capital in a very systematic manner. Their organisation seems to lie excellent and their operatiops ''have leen attended with considerable Ane- cess, though much difficulty has been encountered im tracing their wherahonts. The last exploit i of these gentry was *at Mar- gouclie, practically a quarrymen's village, in the house of a grocer named Mohamed el Guindi, where the malefactors succeeded in peuetrating three walls and blowing open a safe from which they extracted a sum of £90. Happily a further sum of some two thousand pounds, the property of Mohamed Guindi s partner, had been removed previously so that, the haul was much below the anticipations of the enterprising visitors.

The following preliminary note on the Nile Flood of 1907 has been issued by Mr. W. R. Williams, acting Adviser to the Ministry of Public Works

In.the early summer the levels, while better than those of 1905, were appreciably lower than those of the last year. An improvement took place towards the end of April, and though it only lasted for three or four weeks, it sustained the levels northwards for some time and admitted of comparatively easy rotations. About the middle of May, howewer, the levels up country dropped considerably and at Rosseires actually touched those of 1905, and though the flood began to rise within the usual time, it was weak from the commencement and has since been interrupted by intervals during which the river level has varied but slightly. Although the Atbara showed a marked rise recently at Khashm el Girba and there were fair rains in the Northern Sudan which were beneficial locally, they were not widespread and had practically no effect on the Nile itself.

Owing to the weak approach of the flood, considerable care has hail to be exercised in the regulation at the Assouan dam so as to provide an ample supply for the irrigation of cotton and summer crops and Sharaki sowings, and at the same time to keep sufficient reserve in- the reservoir to avoid its being emptied too soon. This has been very effectively carried out and the dam has again proved of invaluable assistance, and, in spite of the weak beginning of the flood, it has enabled the removal of the Sharaki decree prohibition from tho 21st. July in the Northern Provinces of the Delta and from the whole of Upper and the remainder of Lower Egypt between the 25th and the end of the month.

Captain Lyons, who has gone very carefully into the question, has snpplied meteorological data and notes regatding the rain-fall and levels which go to show that the former have been most unsatisfactory in Abyssinia, where the rains have been persistently weak throughout.

At the present time, the gauge at Rosseires is over 1.50 metres below the average of the last seven years (1900 to 1906) all of which were years of flood which were well under theaverage ; and at Khartoum at the time of writing, the river has touched the low level, on the same date, of the year 1905.

The rain-fall of June seems to have been on the whole as much as 50 % deficient, and that of July nearly 30 % ; but news has just come that the rain-fall during the last few days has shown an improvement and Rosseires lias begun to rise a little. Even, however, if the rains of August and September were to be fully up to the average, it looks as if we may expect a flood of about 15 % below the normal of previous years : while, if the latter portion of the rainy season proves bad, the flood volume may fall to ns much as 20 or 25% below the average.

To sura up therefore, the flood is backward and weak and though the cotton and summer irrigation and late summer Sharaki sowings are proceeding satisfactorily owing to the assistance of the Assouan reservoir, there may be some difficulty in irrigating some of the higher basin hmds in Middle Egypt and East Giza ; and unless tho rainfall shown marked improvements in August and September, the flood 'will remain a low one.

div.head:
THE EGYPTIAN CRISIS-
MEETING OF MESSRS SAHAL'S - CREDITORS.
div.p: At the meeting of the creditors of Messrs Sahal Brothers, held at the Chartered Accountants' Rooms, Manchester, on Monday week, Messrs Murgatroyd, Shuttlewortb, and Haworth, chartered accountants, submitted a statement of affairs which showed total assets £317,926, and liabilities £211,942, leaving a surplus of £105,984, Mr. Charles L. Samson, (Messrs, Grundy, Hershaw and Co., solicitors, Manchester), who represented Messrs. Sahal and Co., explained that, the present position had been brought about by the recent financial crisis in Egypt. After discussion a resolution was passed unanimously to the effect that Messrs. Sahal and Co. should continue to carry on their business under the supervision of three inspectors—Messrs, .1. P. Garnett, A. D. Harvey, and E. F. Stockton. Among those present representing firms interested were Messrs. R. A. Edgar (Messrs. Boote and Edgar), Mr. H. Agnew (Messrs. Sale, Seddon, and Co.). Mr. J. P. Garnett (Messrs. David Smith, Garnett, and Co.), and Mr. II, L. Price.

A supplement to the Official Journal of Saturday's date contains the following im portant statement on the Cairo WaterSupply:— For some time past complaints have been addressed to the Sanitary Administration upon the subject of the had quality of drinking water supplied to the inhabitants of Cairo. Articles have appeared in the journals and in fact general complaint has been made that the water is infected, and is the primary cause of the increased mortality among infanta, which of late has been so noticeable. It is in the first place absolutely untrue, as has been alleged, that the Sirdar had addressed to the Administration a complaint upon the quality of the water. As to the above complaints a sufficient answer will be found in the declarations.; made last year in a report published in the.
79 (supplement).

The water of the artesian wells comes from a depth of 60 metres and is free of all bacteria, a statement proved by the examinations and analyses made by several independent experts. The water after leaving the wells iB equally free from any pathogenic microbes.

There is no reason then to consider the water of the artesian wells as unwholesome. The increased mortality among*infants observed this year cannot be due to the water from these wells, because at this particular period of last year the town was snpplied in the same manner by this water.

The increase of infant mortality among children in the summer is equally noticeable in Europe, and is due to several causes of which the following are principal: (1) The weakening effect of the heat itself; (2) the usage of goods insufficiently nourishing or adulterated, (3) and, in general, the lack of care which is so necessary to the well being of every child.

In certain quarters of the town the inhabitants complain that the water has a bad odour. ThiB odour iR due to the Nile water which during the low water season, particularly in June and July, has often a bad smell, which it is impossible to prevent even by the best filterage.

The number of artesian wells sunk up to the present is not entirely sufficient for the needs of the town. The Water Company is therefore forced to obtain a part of its supply from other sources, and as particularly concerns the one of which complaint is mi a certain quantity of water from the Nile passes through sand filters. When Cairo was entirely supplied with Nile water t$iAbath odour was always perceived at the tiara of the low water (Jane and July), and disappeared at the period of the rise upon the arrival of the fresh water.

The public justly claims that the water taken from the taps has occasionally a darkish appearance. This is dneto the fact that the water from the artesianr wells contains in its origin a minute solution of iron and magnesia. This is precipitated in an insoluahle form chiefly under the influence of a fungus, well known under the name of Crenothrix. This fungus can not live or increase in water containing a solution of iron or magnesia, from which it causes a precipitation in the form of a black deposit Neither the iron or the magnesia are in any way dangerous to health.
The Crenothrix is a fungus absolutely inoflesive and which is in no way dangerous or of a pathogenic nature. This is clearly stated in several excellent journals.

Its presence in the water, from a technical point of view is only to be feared, because by the precipitation of the iron' and the magnesia, it troubles the water and sometimes causes abundant precipitations which obstruct a free delivery of water to the houses.
It is contended therefore that this darkening of the water is certainly a little disagreeable but is in no way dangerous.
This inconvenience caused by the presence of Crenothrix, is produced in many of the villages of Europe.
One can easily free the water supplied from any sign ot iron or magnesia by the use of special filters.

Under the Council of the Sanitary Administration, the Water Company decided several months ago upon the installation of certain filters of which they have made a special study, but naturally a complete installation cannot be made in a day or two. It will take at least a year. Until then the public must be patient and endeavour to remedy the inconvenience of which they complain, by themselves filtering the water and when it is seen to contain iron to pass it through cotton wool, but there is no leaspn whatever to be alarmed and to fear that the state of the water actually implies a danger to the public health.

In conclusion a comparative table of water analyses is given from different sources and different periods, and from which it can be seen that the water from the artesian wells at Rodel-Faraq, though being a little more charged with mineral salts than the Nile Water, is not more so than the water of Zeitoun of which no complaint has been made, the water of Tantah, and the celebrate water of Evian.

div.head: SPEECHES OF EDITORS-
div.p: The Egyptian Committee gave a dinner at the Hotel Mdtropole on the 25th ult. to the Egyptian Nationalists now in this country—Sheik Ali Bey Yussef, Hafiz Effendi Awad, Hassan Bey Sabry, Dr. Bahgat Wahby, Sheik Moursy Mahmoud, and M Akhnookh Fanous, Mr. J. M. Robertson, M. P., presided, and the company included Mr. By lea, M. P., Sir H. Cotton; M. P., Mr. G. Greenwood, M. P., Mr. Gotland, M.P., Sir George Kekewich, M.P., Mr. Laidlaw, M.P., Mr. McCailum, M.P., Mr. A. C. Morton, M.P., Mr. O'Grady, M.P., Mr. Radford, M.P., Dr. Rutherford, M.P„ Mr. Smeatoii, M.P., Sir Thomas Barclay, and Mr. Pox Bourne.

After the toasts of "The King" and "The Khedive." The Chairman propeeed that of "Oar Guests. He said the object of the gathering r r__ was to promote good will on earth. These were the days of ententes cordiales among nations who used to regard themselves as inevitable enemies.

. There had lately been an entente cor- diale between England and Russia and, although there had been a good doalof opposition to that, no one would suggest a whisper of opposition to the suggestion that there ought to be an entente oordiale between England and Egypt. Anything that helped to draw ns closer together deserved the sympathy and support of every lover of civilization. People nowadays were beginning to see that a great deal of the bad blood and strife of the past might have been prevented if men had begun to shake brands before quarrelling rather than after. One of their hopes was that that gathering might help in preventing the growth of any such friction between England and Egypt in the future as had had to be regretted in the past as between England and Ireland and even latterly between England and India. Thus far the situation was perfectly healthy: The feeling of Egyptians towards this country was essentially one of good will. There was nothing in the nature of a deep or sincere anti-English feeling in Egypt. They hoped by that gathering to develop sympathy between the two peoples. Egyptians were not extremists. They were simply asking that the promises that were made over 20 years agp and held ontfin the Constitution drawn up by Lord Dufferin should be gradually and reasonably fulfilled. (Cheers).

Hafiz Effendi Awad, responding in English, said, the cause be pleaded was that Egyptians might be allowed to take their right and proper share in the administration of their own affairs. They had a Khedive who reigned, but did not rule. They had Ministers, governors of provinces, and other high officials whose posts wwe'tnere sinecures. They possessed neither _ rity>n«r responsibility It'was the British nirho ran themoohine of Government m all its various details ; and there was this peculiarity and grave inconvenience, that the Englishmen who were in the service of the Egyptian Government, and who received their salaries from such Government, took their orders from, and were responsible for their action to, not the Egyptian Government, but the British Consul- General alone. That was an abnormal condition of affaire which should not be allowed to continue indefinitely. It was their belief that the time had now arrived when, following upon the lines laid down in Lord Dufferia's scheme, a step forward might prudently be taken for endowing Egypt with constitutional capacity. They did not ask for power to revise treaties, or to alter their relations, financial and otherwise, with European States. They did not ask that they should be enabled to legislate where foreigners resident in Egypt were concerned. All that they asked, for the present at least, was that they should be enabled to legislate fti matters administrative, educational, judicial, and financial, which solely appertained to their own people. To accomplish their aims they proposed to do nothing that should savonr of revolution, but to employ solely constitutional methods. If it be decreed that Egypt ipust fall under the domination of a foreign Power, they preferred in their heart of hearts that that Power should be England. But they appealed to the British nation to aid them in realizing what they believed to be their reasonable aspirations. (Cheers.)

Sheik Ali Bey Yussef, who also responded, said the English occupation t>f Egypt took place under abnormal circumstances, and it was never intended by the authors of the occupation that Egypt should become a British colony. He felt assured that if at any time the occupation should cease, in accordance with the pledges originally given, England would find in Egypt a grateful ally and a loyal partner in the country over which their united flags waved. The Egyptians were patting forward certain demands, and it would, in his view, exhibit England in a noble light before the whole world were she to accede to them. If they were asking that education should be rendered free to the whole nation, it was because they knew that that was the only means of elevating the masses. If they asked that the system of higher education be rendered more thorough lhan at present, it showed the level to which the educated classes in Egypt had already attained. And if they asked that all knowledge Bhould be imparted in their native tongue, it was because they knew that a nation could not take its rightful share in the advancement of science save under suoh conditions. If they asked that Egyptians who were competent for government employ should be preferred to aliens, they were only vindicating a just claim. And if they asked thattbe Legislative Council and General Assembly should be endowed with legislative powers, it was because legislation in an alien garb could never be wholly satisfactory tola people whose national conscience was awakening. Furthermore, if they asked that criminal oases in which Europeans were charged, should be transferred from the Consular Courts to the mixed tribunals, it was becanse it was the simpler course These were the principal demands prescribed by the General Assembly whom was recently convened. A general discussion followed.

div.head: THE MEGLIS ELHASBY:
div.p: To thb Editor op tub "Eqtptiax Gazette. "

Sir,—One of the departments of the Egyptian legal administration, which is greatly in need of reform, is the Meglis el-Hasby. I will give you a case in point Some years ago, in 1904, the Meglis el-Hasby at Alexandria appointed a trustee to my father's property. This trustee did not execute his trust in an equitably maimer.

In 1906 I brought an action against the trustee. The Sub-Governor of Alexandria, Hafez Bey Mohamed, supported the trostee with his influence and I could not get a judgment in the Meglis el-Hasby. I then appealed to Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, and set all the facts of the case before him. He at once settled the matter to my satisfaction. This was in last June. Naturally I expected that after the Adviser had interfered I could obtain satisfaction, but as he has gone to Europe on leave I find that it is utterly impossible for me to get anything done at the Meglis. The influence ot Hafez Bey Mohammed has again been brought to bear on the matter. I consequently have been obliged to furnish you with this information as the publicity, which will thereby ensue to the case, might possiby do some good to the public in general. I have given the exact facts and am perfectly willing to take the fullest responsibility for my statements, which I guarantee to be entirely correct in ever}' detail.
Truly Yours Mohamed Abdul Khalik Ismail.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S £50,000-
div.p: M. Harduin, commenting in the "Matin" on the proposed grant of £50,000 to Lord Cromer for his services in Egypt, sayft:—"LonLCromer ought to be thankful that he was born in England, and that it was to that country that he rendered his eminent service. If he had been bom in France, and had rendered similar servioes, the only result would have been that the official "Gazette" would have published on its front page a decree appointing him "Grand- offioer" of the Legion ofHononr. The noble and disinterested spirit of a Frenchman is supposed to be content .with the possession of a beautiful red ribbon which he can put on, and, contem plating himself in the mirier, think of the glory which is reflected by his person. The Englishman, being without poetry, prefers good pounds sterling—he looks at the comfort which they will ensure for Kim."

div.head: WAGNER AT SAN STEFANO.
div.p: Nearly fifty years ago, when Princess Pauline de Mettemich Sandor introduced Wagner's music to the Court of Napoleon III. she was unable to obtain an audience. Could she have seen the music.

A blue sky over an emerald sea, waves dancing in the Bunlight and a cool breeze, bringing with it a sensation of languourous contentment, were elements calculated to enhanoe the enjoyment of the conoert given by the Bracale orchestra. Apart from actual stage representations of the operas, I prefer to hear Wagner out-of-doore and the conditions at San Stefano compare favourably with those in which we listen to a concert in the Queen's Hall (for example), even though the orchestra be the famous one presided over by Mr. Henry J. Wood. Every member of the orchestra (which was considerably augmented for the ocoaaion and included two ladies who lent their valuable aid) played 'con aroore.'

I am not a perfeot Wagnerite, I have never made the pilgrimage to Bayreuth, nor is my calling that of a musical critic but I profess an ear for music, and this was wholly satisfied. I preferred the first item in the programme, the pi elude to the third act of ' Lee Maltres Chanteurede Nuremberg," but the "RMeof of the Valkyries" was admirably performed and reoeived an enthusiastic encore.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: We regret to learn that Sir Auckland Colvin, K.C.8.I., K.C.M.G., C.I.E., chairman of the Egyptian Delta Light Railway Company, is lying somewhat seriously ill at his home in Suffolk.

Captain Adams, R.E., general manager of the Egyptian Delta Light Railway Company Ltd., has left England for his home in Canada, where be will spend six weeks prior to returning to this country via London.

At the last meeting of the governing body of Battersea Polytechnic, Mr. E. Tate, the chairman, on behalf of the governors, presented Principal S. H. Wells with a Silver reproduction of an ancient Irish vase. Mr. Wells is leaving England shortly to take up the duties as Director-General of Education and Agriculture in Egypt. In making the presentation Mr. Tate spoke of the eminent services rendered to the Battersea Polytechnic by Mr. Wells.

Surgeon-Colonel Edmund Greswold McDowell, C.B., who died at Portland last week, took part in the Egyptian campaign of 1882, and received the medal, 3rd Class of tKe Medjidieh, and the Khedive's Star. He also served in the. Sudan expedition under Sir Gerald Graham in 1884 as principal medical officer, and was present in the engagements of El Teb and Tamai. He was twice mentioned in despatches, and for his Wives was made a companion of the Bath.

div.head:
THE INSCRIPTIONS OF SINAI
AN INTERESTING DISCVERY.
div.p: For some years past travellers in Sinai have noticed a number of curious inscription* 6a the rock* in the wadis or valleys of the Psoinsula.

The earliest traveller to note and copy these graffiti was the Indian explorer Foster, who passed through the country on his way to the Far East in the early part of the eighteenth centnry. This traveller unhesitatingly ascribed them to the Israelites, who, aooording to his theory, inscribed them during their forty years' • wanderings. Others again attributed then to pious pilgrims to Sinai, while some were of opinion that they were the woric of shepherds. Against this last theory it was urged that few, if any of the modem Bedouin or shepherds of the district can either read or write, how much less therefore those of the firet and second centuries to which date the inscriptions of Sinai certainly belong. All these theories have now been finally disposed of by the recent researches of Professor Eutiny, who has made a systematic examination of the whole district in which they are found, and has carefully studied and published the texts. The real authors of these inscriptions turn out to have been Nabathtean traders, who from time to time passed < through the Sinaitic Peninsula with their caravans to the markets of Egypt and Palestine, and who thus left behind them the records of their visits. The chief importance of the Sinaitic inscriptions lies in the fact that they represent the transitory stage of Nabathieah on the one hand and Neski Arabic on the other.

div.head: Racked with Rheumatism.
div.p: "For a period of 12 or 13 /years," says Mr. Thomas Little, 5 Bloch, Caledonian Buildings, Motherwell, Scotland, "I was constantly troubled with rhempatism ; so bad was it at times that I had to givte up work. I dttrilmte my illnes* to a chill; when I had anything like (kycold it fiew to my kidneus. The urinary secretions were cloudy ana bill of sediment. But 'my worst trouble was, I was crippled by sciatica and rheumatism. The pain was terrible in my left hip and thigh ; the sinews on my leg seemed to be contracted, for I could not putr my heel to the ground. I could not straighten my leg, and could only step on my toes. There was an awful, constant gnawing pain. My shoulders and arms, also were full of aches; jny knee, troubled me, being badly swollen for years. The pain in my back, especially over the right kidney, was just as if a knife had been stuck into me.

"This will give you some idea of my suffering. Then I read of the cure by Doans Backache HidnSy Pills of a case similar to mine, andVtecided to give them a trial. It was a happy resolve. Before I had finished the first box my back1was easier; not only that, but the rhedtatatism was much easier in my leg. I continued With the pills, and was cured. I need scarcely say I esteem them a most wonderful medicine."

div.head:
POWERS.
NAY AL AND MILITARY PREPARATIONS

div.p: The l|attle*hips SufTren, Charlemagne and Kepublique, and the cruisers Jules-Ferry, Victor Hugo, and Deaaix are preparing here to sail. Three transports have been ordered in order to convey 2,500 troops to Morocco.
(Reuter)
The British cruiser Antrim has been ordered to hold itself in readiness for peremptory service. (Reuter)

3000 Algerian troops and certain regiments quartered in Southern Spain are going to Morocco. It is believed they will remain until the new police force has been installed in the eight ports designated in the Algeciras treaty. • * (Renter)
Prance and Spain continue to negotiate, an agreement for the landing of the necessary troops at Casablanca for, the protection of Europeans-and the punishment of the guilty.
. . (11 aval)
' The cruiser* "Glore," "Jean d'Arc," and the "Niva" have left for Morocco. (Hava*)
The cruisers "Gloiro" and "Jeanne d'Arc" ami n transport have started for Morocco. (R.)
too refugees have arrived from Casablanca where a terrible panic prevails. (Reuter)
The press is strongly opposed to the active participation ol Spain'in action regarding the Casablanca incident. (Reuter)

div.head:
BRITISH NAVAL REVIEW.
A MAGNIFICENT SIGHT.

div.p: , The King and Queen reviewer! the Home Fleet consisting of ] 88 vessels in the Solent. The. Swedish squadron participated. The lidos covered 24 miles and were a most impressive spectacle. The weather was fine.

The review was a superb pageant. The warships wore moored in seven purallel linos,ut the head of one of which the "Dreadnought" was stationed. The King and Queen steamed down between the lines and were tremendously cheered. ^ *

Thunderous salutes were fired from the bedecked warships. An interesting feature was the presence of II submarine*. At nightfall the ships were illuminated from truck to waterline. The King decorated the admirals with the Victorian Order. (Reuter)

The Commission has adopted the American proposal to establish a permanent Arbitration Court The new Court will adjudicate on ' judicial questions. It will not interfere with the Tribunal created in 189jl which is to-be available for political disputes. (Reuter)

div.head:
STANDARD OIL COMPANY.
MAXIMUM PINE INFLICTED.

div.p: The Standard Oil Co. has lieen fined W,240,000 dollars, the legal maximum, for receiving rebates. (Reuter)

Two motor cars collided, one from the French criterion) and the other oocupied by journalist*. Six peoplo were killed and two ipjured. The Government ha* forbiddon the continuance of the race. (Hava*)
A train whilst proceeding from Angers to Foiters was derailed at the bridge over the Loire and was precipitated into the river. 40 persons are missing. 13 corpses have been recovered. ^ (Reuter)
A locomotive traversing the bridge of Bnce fell into the Loire with a compartment full of people. 40 persons disappeared. 18 bodies have been recovered. (Hava*)

The Norddeutsche Zeitung has published an Article concerning the meeting of the Tsar and the Emperor William. The Tsar, it says, undertaking this journey into Germaij waters is returning the Emperor's visit of 1905. This meeting conforms with ancient customs which are pleasantly maintained on both wiles, and it is a new manifestation of the friendship which the two monarchs have received as a tradition from their ancestors, and which is laithfully goarded. The principal objeot of their visits to Swinemunde is a personal one. There is no political motive for their meeting and it cannot be looked npon by any one with suspicion or distrust.
In Germany the Tsar's visit is received with satisfaction as a manifestation of the cordial existing between the'two dynasties and the two Empires, which are united by so many ties. k % (Reuter)
The Tsar and the Emperor William mot here and exchanged visits on their respective yaojfts. . f • s (Reuter)
Emperor William and the Tsar have had two interviews 011 board their respective yachts. (Hava*)

Mr. Birrell went to Ireland yesterday even ing in connection with the troubles in Belfast where the strike of coal-mcn has been settled. The authorities are dispersing the disaffected members of the police to remote districts and are drafting in steady long-service men. (R.)
The strike dispute* have been practically settled. The police agitation is subsiding.
A mob attacked an unescorted lorry and burned the contents and throw tjio lorry in the river. (Reuter)
At the elections of General Councils the protesting winegrowers' candidates for the province of Hernult have been elected/Hava*)
The elections have resulted in a triumph for the nationalist who demand independence, freedom to darry arms, establishment of jury trials, and representation on the Philippine commission. (Reuter)

div.head: THE IONIAN BANK-
div.p: As a branch of the Ionian Bank is shortly to be opened in this city, and a* it is a bank of vory old standing, having boon founded in 1839, it will be interesting to our readers that we should give a short history of its antecedents.

According to the custom of the times when these banks were founded, whioli custom still prevails in Greece, they were respectively formed under Conventions with the Government* of tho Ionian Republio, and the Greek kingdom, and in the case of the former, fn conformity with Act 78 of the Fourth Session of the Fifth Parliament, which by Art 1 vested in tbe Executive Government the ueoinary powers,

' This law, then in force in the Ionian Republic, was understood to be based on the Venetian, and therefore ultimately on the Roman Low. Under it the character and attributes of a corporate body attach at onoe upon an association acting nnderan aggregate name, without designation of the individuals who compose it-; but as the law had not been reduced into a recognised ooae, and as associations in the nature of joint stock companies were new to the Ionian Islands, it was considered indispensable that the requisite powers for enabling the Bank to act in its aggregate capacity, as an individual subject of tho states, should be conferred by means of a Convention in express terms. *

In great Britain, before the introduction of the Joint Stock Companies' Acts, a somewhat similar procedure was requisite, sod the agreement concluded with the crown, including the statutes of the company, was called a charter. Here, in Egypt, foreign cotnpam validly constituted, are wholly independent of any Government authorization or control ; but a Firman of His Highness the Khedive, approving of the conditions contained in the articles of association of a company proposing to constitute itself in Egypt, and authorising its formation, is necessary, under Article 46 of the Native Tribunals.

Although tho Ionian Bank is older than the National Bank, by three years, it having been established in 1839, the year Greece was declared an independent kingdom, it did not commence operations in the mainland of Greece, until the year 1864, when the Ionian Islands were coded to Greece; but the commercial relations of the two states during the earlier period of their existence were intimate and necessitated the establishment of agencies by the Ionian Bank in two or three of the towns of Greece.

Practically, the life of these two banks oovers the banking and currency history of the modem kingdom of Greece, and they, alone, of the bonks existing in Greece to-day, passed through the severe financial vicissitudes of tho earlier cxistence of the State ; and from being privileged, and to a certain extent State Banks were specially affected by the currency difficulties between 1881 and 1890-

Whilst the National Bank is distinguished from all other banks in Greece, having regard to the volume of its business, it* semi-official status, it* influence which it exercises through the commanding character of its Govornor.and a large body of shareholders, it* uniqueness of many of it* details of management, and it* suocess of late years, it cannot be said that, in respect of stability, and credit, and thk conservative character of its administration'that it* reputation exceeds that of the Ionian I|ank.

As the Ionian Bank's history is specially bound up with that of the Ionian Islands, a few introductory remarks will explain how Great Britain became specially interested in the Ionian Islands, and how the bauk became established there.
The Ionian Islands lie between the south of Italy and the west ooast ot Greece, immediately off the south west coast of Albania, and they figure in the ancient history of Greece.
Originally, Corfou, one of the Seven Inlands, was colonised by the Corinthians, and the
earliest natal engagement in history wee that in 684B.C. between the Corfiotes (Corcyreh) and the Corinthians.
Tn the 15th Century, tho Seven Inlands passed into the hands of the Venetians.

As Venice left her indelible mark in the social characteristics, and political economy of these islanders, it is os well to point oat that Venice was more of a Greek than an Italian town, dating from the Latin conquest of Constantinople; and the state, of. which it was the ohief town, woe a patrioion Republio oopied from Bysontine model. | Subsequently, on the arrival of the Turks in the Peloponnessns, they drove out the reigningpredatory Greeks, the military element who dominated that oountiy, and who owned ollegianoe to the emperors of the east, and there, under the name of "Eetrodjoto," become military settlers in the Venetian State, and in other States who sought them as mercenaries.

Of the Venetians, Dante thus speaks, in a letter he wrote to Guido da Polenta — "it is "not a thing to make marvel, that they (the "Venetians) do not know how to speak Italian, 'Tor they are descended from Dalmatians "and Greeks." Seeing the oloee connetion between1 the Venetians and the Ionians, it will be readily understook that the settlement of the Venetians in the Seven Islands partook of a peaceable ooonpation.

In the 18th century, the Seven Islands were first token by the Frenoh, who, in their turn, were expelled by the Russians and the Turks ; and early in the 19th century, by the Treaty of Tilsit, Russia ceded them to France.
Franoe oocupied them from 1807 until 1809, exoept Corfu, which she did not surrender until 1814.
Between 1809 and 1814, thoy were gradually token possession of by the British troops.

Tbe importance of the Ionian Islands, as a military and naval post, was well knowb, and, also, that Venice made Corfu her ohief arsenal and odvanoe-post for her operations in the East. It wes these considerations, and that they were oocupied by the French, that induced the British to capture them. When they did so, thoy made Zante the capital, and it became the head quarters of the British forces and Admiralty.
In 1815, by the Treaty of Parte, which the Ionian* considered their Magna Charto, they were placed under the protection of Great Britain.
From the first birth of their independence by Art. 9, of the Treaty of Aipiens, they were the objeot of considerable interest to the great powers.

They had a Senate, which were a restoration ot the Venetian plan of administration, and a Legislative Assembly, and they assumed the title of the United States of "the Ionians islands;" but they were practically ruled by tlie British Lord High Commissioner.
The Ionian Bank was projected by the Lord' High Commissioner, Lieutenant General Sir Howard Douglas.

lie suggested it* formation as a means for remedying the many grievances and exactions which the necessitous small landowners were enduring from tbe local money lenders, who bought up their harvest of oil and currants every year.

Overtures were made by him in the year 1838, through the medium of Sir Alexander Wood, the Agent in London for the Ionian 8tatos, to oertoin capitalist* in England, for the formation of a Company, which resulted in the Ionian Bank being formed with a capital of £100,000, and a invention was finally granted to the bank by the United States of the Ionian Islands, on the 23rd October 1839.

On the 2nd March 1840, the bank was opened for business at Corfu, on the 18th May at Zante, and on the 10th August at Cephalonia In 1844, the bonk applied to the British Governments and obtained a charter subject to the usual conditiona In 1864, Mr. Gladstone, by the Treaty of London, with the three Great Powers, who signed the Treaty of Paris, procured the anion of the Septinsulsr Republic with the Kingdom of Greece.

Mr. Gladstone was influenced in this stage, not only by the dictates of his own sympathetic spirit, but by the political unrest ofthe Ionians of Greek origin, who considered themselves deprived of their just rights and liberties under the Treaty of Paris, by their constitutional remonstrances against the administration of the Islands by some ofthe high-salaried British officials; and by their natural desire for unity with Greece, whose independonoo was guaranteed by the Great Powers. i

Tbe official transfer of the Islands was carried out by 8ir H. K. Stevens one of whose Secretaries at the time, wa* Mr. Evelyn Baring, now Lord Cromer-Under this Treaty, the right* and privileges of the Ionian Bank, as far as they were comprised in its original convention, and renewals of the same, were protected and guaranteed by the three Great Powers and Greece.

Thenceforth, it became a privileged bank in Greece, and had to enter into communication with the Greek Government for tho purpose of ascertaining and defining its status The result was, that it obtained the right by convention to carry on its business throughout the newly constituted Kingdom ; and all the privileges and advantages accorded to the National Bank of Greece, regarding legal procedure, were conceded to it.

It also obtained the right to issue notes, on its own account, up to 9 million drachmas ; and, on Government aoconnt, up to 3} millions; which notes under the forced currenoy law* became legal tender In 1882, the Ionian Bank Act wa* passed, by whioh the Royal Charter, which had become antiquated, was determined, and power was
liven to register the Bonk under the English Companies' Acte u a Limited Company, which was done on the 5th March 1888.

The Bank in it* profit*^has reflected the ohinging economic conditions of Greece, bat it hoe never failed to pay an annual dividend to it* shareholders, and for the last three years ho* declared a uniform dividend of 6 per cent, and has added to its reserves.

The oaretul administration of the duties of the International Financial Commission, and of the public finances by tho various Governments which have held power from 1898, in otroperation with the Commission, have opened up a new era for Greece, wnd for the banking establishment* there.

And the stability of the finance* of the country under the condition* of the arrangement arrived at in 1898, and the great natural enhancement of the paper drachma to almost par, and the re-establishment of confidence, confirm the belief that the country will continue it* progress.

It is also to be expected, that, shortly, the inconvertible bank-note, as far as Greece is concerned, will became a discarded tool, a dark vision of an unwholesome financial part, and substance, in the shape of gold, will ofice more reign as the means and measure of the exchange of wealth, and the reservoir of loanable capital.

The entension of the commercial relations of Greece with foreign parts, and especially with Egypt, and the competition of the local banks which renders the employment of money in Greece comparatively nnreinandrative, and the attraction!! of this progessive and economically sound country have induced the authorities of the Bank to establish a Branch here.

There cannot be a doubt that the Bank ha* arrived in Egypt at an opportune moment, wbpn the business public are smarting frotn the disappointments and losses of severe financial crisis, and will be ready to weloome the facilities which a bonk new to this field may offer; and when Greeks, especially, who are numerous here, will be more inclined to rally round an institution which they have known from their childhood.

The Bank's capital is small in comparison with tnany of the important institutions already established here, only about £400,000 including its reserves; but we understand there is an intention of increasing the capital should circumstances warrant this step being taken.
